My AI Code Prep & Cline Workflow for Budget Coding/Debugging (Part 1)
ailarge language modelllmagentic workflowssoftware developmentcodingdebuggingworkflowai toolscontext windowprompt engineeringcost optimizationfree tierlocal developmentopenrouterpoegeminiclaudegithub copilotcligui
  • Strategy: Leverages multiple free-tier web-based AI models (GLM 4.5, Kimi K2, Gemini 2.5 Pro, Claude 4 via OpenRouter/Poe) for coding and debugging to maximize capability without cost.
  • Core Problem Addressed: AI coding agents like Cline or Github Copilot often fail by sending excessive or insufficient context, which "dumbs down" the model and leads to poor results.
  • Proposed Workflow:
    1. Use a tool called "AI Code Prep GUI" to recursively scan a local project folder.
    2. The tool intelligently suggests relevant files, excluding patterns like node_modules and .git, while allowing the user to manually curate the final file selection via a GUI.
    3. It generates a formatted context block containing the content of the selected files.
    4. Paste this curated context into a powerful, free web-based AI to analyze the problem and devise a solution.
    5. Use the generated solution to prompt a less sophisticated (or cheaper) model via a coding agent to execute the file edits.
  • Key Tooling: "AI Code Prep GUI" is a cross-platform (Windows, Mac, Linux, web) application that works with local/private codebases and provides a graphical interface for context selection.
  • Prompt Engineering Technique: The tool can optionally place the user's prompt both before and after the code context block, a method suggested to improve the AI's focus on the specific query.
Claude Code Is All You Need
claude codeanthropicaillmagentic workflowsautonomous agentcode generationvibe codingnatural language programmingsoftware developmentterminalcliproductivityautomationproduction migrationcrudphpsqlnodejsnginxlaravelmysqlhackernewsbrowser extensiondata processingtui
  • Core Tool: The article focuses on "Claude Code," a terminal-based AI assistant from Anthropic.
  • Methodology ("Vibe Coding"):
    • Refers to developing applications via natural language prompts without directly writing code.
    • The author finds that detailed specifications and simple, vanilla tech stacks (e.g., a single PHP file, raw SQL) yield the best results. Complex frameworks often lead to over-engineered, non-functional outputs.
  • Use Cases & Experiments:
    • CRUD App Generation: Successfully generated a functional SplitWise clone from a detailed spec file. A prompt specifying a simple PHP/SQL stack worked, while a less constrained prompt produced a broken, dependency-heavy NodeJS project.
    • Autonomous Agent: Deployed on a root VPS with a looping script to build a "startup." The agent self-prompted, chose an idea (server monitoring), and deployed a full-stack web application with Nginx. It required a HUMAN_INPUT.md file for human guidance and was blocked by usage policies when attempting automated marketing.
    • Production Migration: Migrated an unfamiliar Laravel/PHP/MySQL application to a new server. The tool analyzed the codebase to generate a README, then executed the setup and migration, saving an estimated 16-32 hours of manual effort despite some errors (e.g., dropping a database).
    • Tooling: Built a browser extension for ranking HackerNews comments and a web app for creating posters by placing text over AI-generated images and exporting to PDF.
    • Admin Tasks: Used for file system operations (renaming bank statements based on content) and data processing (merging and categorizing expenses from XLSX files into a single CSV).
  • Operational Notes:
    • The author frequently uses elevated permissions (--dangerously-skip-permissions) and bypasses root-user checks (export IS_SANDBOX=1) to give the tool full control.
    • The tool's interactive TUI was used as the author's primary text editor to write the article itself.
Issue 483
haskellliquid haskelltutorialcabalghcreleasesmonadslibrariesperformanceparallelismalgorithmsclitoolscardanoopen source
  • Liquid Haskell Tutorial: Introduction and installation guide for Liquid Haskell (LH), demonstrating its use with a simple example and how to integrate local LH builds.
  • Cabal 3.16 Release: Announces the release of cabal-install and its libraries, version 3.16.0.0. This update adds support for the forthcoming GHC 9.14.
  • Free Monad Transformers: A new library is introduced alongside a discussion on free monad transformers and the Plan 9 operating system.
  • massiv Library Performance: A performance comparison between the vector and massiv libraries using cellular automata examples. The massiv library is shown to offer clearer syntax and significant performance improvements, particularly for parallel computations using features like array stencils.
  • Spiral Matrix Algorithm: A tutorial on solving matrix problems by processing them in layers, building on concepts of mutable arrays in Haskell.
  • GHC 9.10.3-rc1: The first release candidate for GHC 9.10.3 is now available.
  • TaskLite 0.5 Release: A new version of the Haskell/SQLite-based CLI task manager, which also features a GraphQL server and web UI.
  • Werge Mergetool: A new tool that creates and applies word-diff style patches to reduce merge conflicts.
  • Call for Participation: The cardano-ledger project is seeking contributors to rename the PoolParams type to StakePoolParams.
Issue 484
ghcreleasesweederperformancetoolshlshaskell language serverpluginslibrariestypesmonadstutorialopen sourcenixstackclihaskell
  • GHC 9.10.3-rc2: Second release candidate is now available.
  • Weeder 2.10: Released with support for GHC 9.10 and 9.12, featuring significant performance improvements.
  • HLS Plugin: A draft PR is available for a new "Go To Underlying Type" plugin for the Haskell Language Server.
  • Libraries:
    • heterogeneous-comparison: A new library for comparing values of different types while capturing evidence of type equality.
    • twentyseven: A Rubik's cube solver library, has reached version 1.0.0.
    • Dataframe: A call for new contributors has been posted.
  • Articles & Tutorials:
    • An article argues against the necessity of monads, referencing the Я language which does not use them.
    • A tutorial series demonstrates building a bytecode VM and parser for arithmetic.
    • A RealWorld example application built with the effectful library has been open-sourced.
  • Tooling & Development:
    • A developer shared their Nix configuration for a monorepo containing both Haskell and the Lean proof assistant.
    • A discussion is underway to add a shorter command-line alias for the --stack-yaml flag in the Stack build tool.
